data.name: Dataset Title
data.value: Identification of peripheral neural circuits that regulate heart rate using optogenetic and viral vector strategies Link

data.name: Investigators
data.value: Rajendran, Pradeep Sundaram: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9790-0408, Challis, Rosemary C:, Fowlkes, Charless C:, Hanna, Peter:, Tompkins, John D:, Jordan, Maria C:, Hiyari, Sarah:, Gabris-Weber, Beth A:, Greenbaum, Alon:, Chan, Ken Y:, Deverman, Benjamin E:, Munzberg, Heike:, Ardell, Jeffrey L:, Salama, Guy:, Gradinaru, Viviana:, Shivkumar, Kalyanam:

data.name: Description
data.value: Heart rate is under the precise control of the autonomic nervous system. However, the wiring of peripheral neural circuits that regulate heart rate is poorly understood. Here, we developed a clearing-imaging-analysis pipeline to visualize innervation of intact hearts in 3D and employed a multi-technique approach to map parasympathetic and sympathetic neural circuits that control heart rate in mice. We anatomically and functionally identify cholinergic neurons and noradrenergic neurons in an intrinsic cardiac ganglion and the stellate ganglia, respectively, that project to the sinoatrial node. We also report that the heart rate response to optogenetic versus electrical stimulation of the vagus nerve displays different temporal characteristics and that vagal afferents enhance parasympathetic and reduce sympathetic tone to the heart via central mechanisms. Our findings provide new insights into neural regulation of heart rate, and our methodology to study cardiac circuits can be readily used to interrogate neural control of other visceral organs.

data.name: Anatomy
data.value: heart | UBERON:0000948, tissue | UBERON:0000479, heart | UBERON:0000948

data.name: Keywords
data.value: peripheral nervous system, cholinergic, noradrenergic, cardiac autonomic nervous system

data.name: Folder Name
data.value: Identification of peripheral neural circuits that regulate heart rate using optogenetic and viral vector strategies

data.name: Acknowledgement
data.value: We thank the entire Shivkumar and Gradinaru group for discussions. This work was supported by a NIH Stimulating Peripheral Activity to Relieve Conditions (SPARC) awards (OT2OD023848 to K.S. and V.G.; OT2OD23864 to H.M.). The K.S. laboratory is also supported by a NIH National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) grant (R01HL084261) and a NIH SPARC award (U01EB025138-01 to K.S. and J.L.A.). The V.G. laboratory is also supported by a NIH Director's New Innovator Award (DP2NS087949), a NIH Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers, a NIH National Institute on Aging grant (R01AG047664), a NIH BRAIN Initiative award (U01NS090577), the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) Biological Technologies Office, the National Science Foundation NeuroNex Technology Hub (1707316), the Curci Foundation, the Beckman Institute, and the Rosen Bioengineering Center at Caltech. V.G. is a Heritage Principal Investigator supported by the Heritage Medical Research Institute. P.S.R. was supported by a NIH NHLBI F31 Predoctoral Fellowship (F31HL127974). R.C.C. was supported by an American Heart Association Postdoctoral Fellowship (17POST33410404). P.S.R. is a part of the UCLA-Caltech Medical Scientist Training Program. We thank Drs. Marmar Vaseghi (UCLA), Olujimi A. Ajijola (UCLA), and Ching Zhu (UCLA) for their comments.

data.name: Dataset Title
data.value: A multi-scale model of cardiac electrophysiology Link

data.name: Description
data.value: We developed a workflow containing differential equation models of cardiac physiology that automate the execution of simulations with user defined options of outputs from a single cell, 1 or 2D tissue, and a pseudo-ECG output, which can be compared to experimental or clinical data.

data.name: Keywords
data.value: Cardiac Electrophysiology, Workflow, Action potential, pseudo-ECG

data.name: Folder Name
data.value: A multi-scale model of cardiac electrophysiology

Here, we developed a clearing-imaging-analysis pipeline to visualize innervation of intact hearts in 3D and employed a multi-technique approach to map parasympathetic and sympathetic neural circuits that control heart rate in mice. We anatomically and functionally identify cholinergic neurons and noradrenergic neurons in an intrinsic cardiac ganglion and the stellate ganglia, respectively, that project to the sinoatrial node. We also report that the heart rate response to optogenetic versus electrical stimulation of the vagus nerve displays different temporal characteristics and that vagal afferents enhance parasympathetic and reduce sympathetic tone to the heart via central mechanisms. Our findings provide new insights into neural regulation of heart rate, and our methodology to study cardiac circuits can be readily used to interrogate neural control of other visceral organs.

data.name: Dataset Title
data.value: Mapping of ICN Neurons in a 3D Reconstructed Rat Heart Link

data.name: Investigators
data.value: Leung, Clara: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4479-7608, Chen, Jin: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3135-1885, Moss, Alison: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7907-8796, Tappan, Susan: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5120-3770, Heal, Maci: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5097-1030, Huffman, Todd:, Farahani, Navid:, Eisenman, Leonard:, Cheng, Zixi: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3722-6455, Schwaber, James: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0598-7345, Vadigepalli, Rajanikanth: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8405-1037

data.name: Description
data.value: A normal male rat heart was fixed and whole-mount diffusion stained with Cresyl Echt Violet to visualize ICN neurons. The whole heart was sectioned and imaged with a Knife Edge Scanning Microscope (KESM) to produce an image stack. Cardiac anatomy was segmented and single neurons were mapped in the image stack with the Tissue Mapper software. The annotated heart anatomy and distribution of single neurons were then visualized in a 3D reconstructed model of the heart.

data.name: Keywords
data.value: Rodent Cardiac Anatomy, Knife Edge Scanning Microscopy, Rat Intrinsic cardiac neurons

data.name: Folder Name
data.value: Mapping of ICN Neurons in a 3D Reconstructed Rat Heart

data.name: Dataset Title
data.value: Undiseased Human Cardiac Ventricular Cells Link

data.name: Description
data.value: We have created a prototype Cardiac use-case package for modeling and simulation of autonomic effects on the cardiovascular system starting from the human ventricular model developed by O'Hara and Rudy group . The Cardiac use-case package consists of a single-cell model, 1D and 2D tissues models with documentation.

data.name: Keywords
data.value: Computational models, Electrophysiology, Action potential, Isoproterenol, Î²-Adrenergic stimulation

data.name: Dataset Title
data.value: Effects of subcutaneous nerve stimulation on nerve sprouting Link

data.name: Investigators
data.value: Wan, Juyi:, Wong, Johnson: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5838-8453, Chen Peng-Sheng: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4150-5836

data.name: Description
data.value: The rationale of the study was to test the hypothesis that subcutaneous nerve stimulation (ScNS) can remodel the cardiac innervation. We have harvested the tissues, processed them routinely for paraffin embedding and immunohistochemical staining. We include images of growth associated protein 43 (GAP43), tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) staining for LA, RA, LV, RV. In total, 763 JPG images, 3.5 GB.

data.name: Keywords
data.value: nerve sprouting, cardiac nerve sprouting, stellate ganglion

data.name: Folder Name
data.value: Effects of subcutaneous nerve stimulation on nerve sprouting

data.name: Dataset Title
data.value: Electrophysiology in dog after subcutaneous nerve stimulation Link

data.name: Investigators
data.value: Wan, Juyi:, Wong, Johnson: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5838-8453, Chen Peng-Sheng: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4150-5836

data.name: Description
data.value: Electrical signals recorded by 3 pairs of bipolar electrodes under the skin in ambulatory dogs. The sampling rate was 1,000/s. These electrical signals were recorded to detect cardiac arrhythmia and the nerve activity under the skin. The data were analyzed with custom written software (Nerve_Act), which reads the data and apply filters to optimize the arrhythmia detection and nerve activity detection. In total 6658 files and 278.5 GB.

data.name: Keywords
data.value: Electrical stimulation, cardiac arrhythmias, autonomic nervous system, neuromodulation, paroxysmal atrial tachycardia, sympathetic nerve activity

data.name: Folder Name
data.value: Electrophysiology in dog after subcutaneous nerve stimulation

data.name: Dataset Title
data.value: Chronic interfacing with the autonomic nervous system using carbon nanotube (CNT) yarn electrodes Link

data.name: Investigators
data.value: McCallum, Grant A: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5009-914X, Sui, Xiaohong:, Qiu, Chen:, Marmerstein, Joseph:, Zheng, Yang:, Eggers, Thomas E.:, Hu, Chuangang:, Dai, Liming:, Durand, Dominique M:

data.name: Description
data.value: The ability to reliably and safely communicate chronically with small diameter (100â300âÂµm) autonomic nerves could have a significant impact in fundamental biomedical research and clinical applications. However, this ability has remained elusive with existing neural interface technologies. Here we show a new chronic nerve interface using highly flexible materials with axon-like dimensions. The interface was implemented with carbon nanotube (CNT) yarn electrodes to chronically record neural activity from the glossopharyngeal nerve. The recorded neural signals maintain a high signal-to-noise ratio (>10âdB) in chronic implant models. These results establish a novel, chronic platform neural interfacing technique with the autonomic nervous system and demonstrate the possibility of regulating internal organ function, leading to new bioelectronic therapies and patient health monitoring. Chronic neural recordings of glossopharyngeal nerve during hypoxia challenges in anesthetized rats. Intan Technologies amplifiers and acquisition system was used and MATLAB was used for data processing.

data.name: Anatomy
data.value: heart | UBERON:0000948, connective tissue | UBERON:0002384, tube | UBERON:0000025, nerve | UBERON:0001021

data.name: Keywords
data.value: hypoxia, glossopharyngeal nerve, neural recordings, chronic

data.name: Folder Name
data.value: Chronic interfacing with the autonomic nervous system using carbon nanotube (CNT) yarn electrodes

data.value: Drs. Steve Lewis and Y.H. Hsieh (CWRU)

data.name: Dataset Title
data.value: Cholera toxin B retrograde tracing from brown adipose tissue and forelimb to the stellate ganglion. Link

data.name: Investigators
data.value: Lee, Seoeun: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9113-6637, Zeltser, Lori M.: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4330-6240

data.name: Description
data.value: For neuromodulation of stellate ganglion (SG) projections to brown adipose tissue (BAT) to have clinical applications in obesity and type 2 diabetes, it is essential that stimulation protocols avoid projections from the SG to the heart and upper extremities. We mapped the neuroanatomical organization of BAT-projecting SG neurons relative to forelimb-projecting SG neurons in mice. Data consist of 32 stacked images (LSM format) of SG from a Zeiss 710 confocal microscope. Average file size: 540 MB

data.name: Keywords
data.value: retrograde trace, brown adipose tissue, forelimb, cholera toxin B, stellate ganglion

data.name: Folder Name
data.value: Cholera toxin B retrograde tracing from brown adipose tissue and forelimb to the stellate ganglion

data.name: Investigators
data.value: Li Rosemary: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2605-634X, Jimenez-Gonzalez Maria: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7678-9058, Stanley Sarah: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0253-2663

data.name: Description
data.value: The neuronal tracer Cholera Toxin Subunit Beta (CTb) conjugated with a fluorophore (AlexaFluor 488) is infused into the duct of the pancreas. 1 week later neuronal ganglia, including Nodoses, Coeliac and thoracic Dorsal Root Ganglia are harvested. Tissue clearing and staining for CTb is performed using Idisco protocol. Image acquisition is done utilizing a confocal microscope. Further, quantification of CTb positive neurons is assessed using IMARIS software.

data.name: Dataset Title
data.value: AAV Serotypes 6_8_9 Intrapancreatic 4 weeks Link

data.name: Investigators
data.value: Li Rosemary: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2605-634X, Jimenez-Gonzalez Maria: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7678-9058, Stanley Sarah: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0253-2663

data.name: Description
data.value: Adeno-assocciated virus, expressing mCherry fluorophore under synapsin promoter (AAV-hSyn-mCherry) was injected in the parenchyma of the pancreas. Different serotypes (6, 8, 9) were tested. 4 weeks later, coeliacs were harvested. Tissue clearing and immunohystochemistry staining were applied to identify infected neurons. Confocal microscope were used for imaging adquisition. Analysis and quantification were performed with IMARIS software.

data.name: Description
data.value: Adeno-assocciated virus, expressing GFP fluorophore under synapsin promoter (AAVretro-hSyn-GFP) was injected in the parenchyma of the pancreas.. 4 weeks later, coeliac, nodose and dorsal root ganglias were harvested. Creyosection and immunofluorescence staining were applied to identify infected neurons. Confocal microscope were used for imaging adquisition. Analysis and quantification were performed with IMARIS software.
